minutes_text:
VETERANS SERVICES DEPARTMENT
Therese Wrobel, Chairman • Michael Salyers, Vice Chairman
Joel Rutherford, Secretary • Lance Pittman, Member at Large
Manny Gonzales, Member at Large • David Archer, Member at Large
Robert Slavko, Member at Large • Laura Rios, Chief Veterans Service Officer
Mark A. Hackel
County Executive
VETERANS SERVICE COMMITTEE
Tuesday, October 21, 2025
MINUTES
1. Meeting called to order by Chair Wrobel at 11:04AM
2. Pledge of Allegiance and Moment of Silence for our POW’s, MIA’s and the brave men
and women that serve our great Nation so we can meet here today.
3. Adoption of the Agenda. Motioned by Gonzales, 2nd by Salyers. Motion carried.
4. Approval of the Minutes of October 6, 2025. Motioned by Gonzales, 2nd by Slavko.
Motion carried.
5. Public Participation. None
6. Move that the Board meets in closed session, according to the Open Meetings Act to
hear/review requests for assistance. Motioned by Rutherford, 2nd by Gonzales. Motion
carried at 11:07AM
7. Move that the Board returns to open session. Motion by Gonzales, 2nd by Salyers.
Motion carried at 11:30AM
8. Unfinished Business
a. Update on MVAA grants.
b. Tax Program update.
9. New Business
a. One case presented-one case approved.
b. Update on VA and military ID cards.
10. Adjournment: Motion by Gonzales, 2nd by Archer. Motion carried at 11:45AM
Next Meeting October 21, 2025, at 11:00AM
21885 Dunham Road, Suite 3 • Clinton Township, Michigan 48036
Phone: (586) 469-5315 • Fax: (586) 469-5316

minutes_text:
VETERANS SERVICES DEPARTMENT
Therese Wrobel, Chairman • Michael Salyers, Vice Chairman
Joel Rutherford, Secretary • Lance Pittman, Member at Large
Manny Gonzales, Member at Large • David Archer, Member at Large
Robert Slavko, Member at Large • Laura Rios, Chief Veterans Service Officer
Mark A. Hackel
County Executive
VETERANS SERVICE COMMITTEE
Tuesday, November 4, 2025
MINUTES
1. Meeting called to order by Chair Wrobel at 11:01AM
2. Pledge of Allegiance and Moment of Silence for our POW’s, MIA’s and the brave men
and women that serve our great Nation so we can meet here today.
3. Adoption of the Agenda. Motioned by Gonzales, 2nd by Rutherford. Motion carried.
Slavko excused.
4. Approval of the Minutes of October 21, 2025. Motioned by Gonzales, 2nd by Archer.
Motion carried.
5. Public Participation. None
6. Move that the Board meets in closed session, according to the Open Meetings Act to
hear/review requests for assistance. Motioned by Gonzales, 2nd by Salyers. Motion
carried at 11:03AM
7. Move that the Board returns to open session. Motion by Gonzales, 2nd by Salyers.
Motion carried at 12:02PM
8. Unfinished Business
a. Discussion on tax preparation grants.
b. Review of budget for current year.
9. New Business
a. Two cases presented-one case approved and one tabled for more information.
b. Discussion of issues with mortgage relief and ask for guidance from county legal
office and review by county executive’s office.
c. Discussion of holiday party.
10. Adjournment: Motion by Gonzales, 2nd by Salyers. Motion carried at 12:09PM
Next Meeting November 18, 2025, at 11:00AM
21885 Dunham Road, Suite 3 • Clinton Township, Michigan 48036
Phone: (586) 469-5315 • Fax: (586) 469-5316

Information Technology Maintenance requests 2025 – 1st Quarter – Package 2
Note: We must pay our maintenance payments every year to ensure we have the necessary licensing
and maintenance needed to support these systems. We try to co-term them with our Financial year,
but tit is not always possible. The following payments are for the first quarter of 2026. Most of these
have existing agreements and they provide us a quote and/or an invoice to pay. We’ve included the
agreements for the ones that need one signed with this year’s maintenance.
1. Accela
Business case:
This is subscription software paid annually. Accela is used in Public Works ($84,483.16) and
Environmental Health ($123,226.20). This is used to automate manual workflow between divisions,
allows for electronic forms and a web front end for constituents.
Pricing:
Cost this year $207,709.36, last year was $143,008.05. Increase is due to licenses purchased by Public
Works and Environmental Health.
Business case:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$207,709.36.
2. Adobe Systems Licensing via MNJ Technologies
Business case:
This is subscription software paid annually. It is used in most of our departments to create & manipulate
*.pdf documents. It is one of the most common document types in use today. Most administrative staff
have a need for this.
Pricing:
Cost this year $126,159.27, cost last year $112,263.80. The increase is due to more licensing.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$126,159.27.
3. Equivant AKA Courtview
Business case:
Equivant is responsible for the Courtview program software which includes licensing for the following
departments: Circuit Court, Juvenile Court, Juvenile Probation, Probate Court, and Probation Office.
Pricing:
Cost this year $319,980, cost last year $310,961.
BOC Request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software, maintenance & support for $319,980.

4. ESRI
Business case:
ESRI is responsible for the software for the ARC GIS mapping software which includes licensing for the
following departments: Planning, Department of Roads, Public Works, IT, and the Health Department.
Pricing:
Cost this year $110,228.98, cost last year $93,850.62 and reason for the difference, we added licensing.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$110,228.98.
5. eTech – Acella Integrator
Business case:
eTech is the Integrator supporting our implementations of Accela. The support agreement includes
any items that the County needs for enhancements, guidance, and technical support for the following
departments: Public Works and Environmental Health.
Pricing:
Cost this year $38,400. Cost was the same last year.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$38,400.
6. Genesis
Business case:
Genesis is responsible for maintaining the FTR (For the Record) hardware and software in various court
room locations.
Pricing:
Cost this year $105,539, cost last year $100,973. The cost increase is due to a new Probate Court
courtroom.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the maintenance & support for $105,539.
7. Granicus – AKA GovDelivery
Business case:
Granicus/GovDelivery is a cloud service where you can quickly and easily communicate with citizens who
are interested in your services by posting across email, social media, and text messaging. It gives people
the ability to sign-up for updates.
Pricing:
Cost this year $86,271.33, cost last year $92,310.32.

BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software, maintenance & support for $86,271.33.
8. Guidehouse
Business case:
Guidehouse is responsible for the Workday optimization services.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $249,975, cost last year was $396,000.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software, maintenance & support for $249,975.
9. Hyland - Onbase
Business case:
Hyland is responsible to maintain the software of the Court systems.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $126,254.45, cost last year $146,807.49.
BOC Request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software, maintenance & Support for
$126,254.45.
10. IBM QRadar
Business case:
IBM QRadar is responsible to maintain the CJIS Requirements for collecting & reviewing log files of the
Sheriff & the Court systems.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $21,733.67, cost last year $19,345.60.
BOC Request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software, maintenance & Support for $21,733.67.
11. Jotform Enterprise
Business case:
JotForm allows the Applications team to easily and quickly create online forms with complex workflows
using a low code development approach. JotForm has been pursued as an interim, proof of concept
since September of 2021 and has been successful in fulfilling outstanding online form requests
submitted by our County Departments.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $35,715, cost last year was $35,000. Price increase is for additional server and upgrade
to Enterprise account.

BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software, maintenance & support for total of
$35,715.
12. Karpel PBK Prosecutor’s Case Management System
Business case:
Karpel is responsible for the maintenance & support of the Prosecutor Office Case Management system.
Pricing:
The cost this year is $121,250, cost last year $111,100.
BOC Request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$121,250.
13. Leidos
Business case:
Leidos is the Customer Relationship Management software for the Board of Commissioners to improve
citizen engagement, streamlining processes, enhancing data management, increasing transparency,
enabling data-driven decision-making, and facilitating collaboration.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $47,014.96. This is the first maintenance renewal after the initial purchase of the
software.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software, maintenance & support for total of
$47,014.96.
14. LinkedIn Learning
Business case:
LinkedIn is responsible for employee training related to Workday. This has replaced the NeoGov
learning module used by Human Resources.
Pricing:
The cost this year is $53,950, cost last year $46,950.00.
Business case:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$53,950
15. NearMap
Business case:
NearMap's high-resolution aerial imagery, updated frequently, provides accurate views of stormwater
infrastructure, aiding in identification and assessment of assets. The comparative analysis enabled by
historical imagery helps track degradation trends and evaluate past interventions. NearMap's precise

geospatial data ensures accurate asset inventories, enhancing risk assessments and investment planning.
Integration with GIS platforms streamlines analysis, while remote accessibility facilitates collaborative
planning and reduces costs compared to traditional surveys. Leveraging NearMap imagery for public
engagement effectively communicates the SAM, fostering support for proactive stormwater management
and infrastructure resilience.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $30,000.00, this is year 3 of a 3-year contract at $30,000/year.
BOC Request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software, maintenance & Support for $30,000.00.
16. People Driven Technology – InformaCast
Business case:
Informacast is the public address system for the downtown Mt. Clemens buildings software
maintenance & support utilized by all County Departments
Pricing:
The cost this year is $2,035.00. Last year’s was $2,035.00.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the maintenance & support for $2.035.00.
17. People Driven Technology – Poly
Business case:
People Driven Technology is responsible to maintain the support for our Poly server and software which is
used to maintain the Polycom units at the Courts and Jail.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $3,225.58, cost last year was $8,107.08 but last year included an upgrade to the system
with professional services that is not in scope this year.
BOC Request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$3,225.58.
18. People Driven Technology – Dell PowerProtect
Business case:
Dell PowerProtect is used to restore data backups from the cloud to on-premises, so the data is usable.
Pricing:
The cost this year is $24,691.64. This is our first year paying for maintenance directly after the purchase
in 2020 that included 5 years of maintenance.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the maintenance & support for $24,691.64.

19. Placer Labs
Business case:
Placer.ai is an annual software-as-a-service subscription that provides the County with detailed location
analytics which is utilized to track and analyze venue/site visitation patterns and visitor characteristics
and habits. It is one of our primary economic development analysis tools utilized for site selection, site
impact assessment and corridor and neighborhood analysis. There was additional licensing this year.
Pricing:
This Cost $45,513. Cost last year was $42,142.
Business case:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$45,513.
20. Qualtrics
Business case:
Qualtrics is responsible to maintain the support for licensing, this upgrades the County to the Enterprise
CX platform and will allow the Qualtrics solutions to be leveraged and used by and department up to
150 new admin users.
Pricing:
The cost this year is $813,798.99. Last year’s was $810,419.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the maintenance & support for $813,798.99.
21. RP Pro - Abnormal Security
Business case:
Abnormal Security is our inbound email security and email account takeover protection service. Used to
detect advanced threats and fully automates threat prevention and response.
Pricing:
The cost this year is $79,800. Cost last year was $76,000.
Business case:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$79,800.
22. SecurityScorecard
Business case:
Security Scorecard is a tool that monitors third-party vendor risks related to network security, patching
cadence, endpoint security, IP reputation, application security, hacker chatter and more to help determine
the risks associated with doing business with vendors. It rates them on an A-F scale to have targeted
discussions with the vendor about certain aspects of their ratings. This will allow full transparency and
trust with our vendors to make sure they are valuing their network security as much as we value ours.

Pricing:
This Cost $51,817.50. Cost last year was $49,350.
Business case:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual software subscription, maintenance & support for
$51,817.50
23. Ten7
Business case:
Ten7 is responsible for optimizing services of the County website and implementing secure access to
department webpages by Content Editors. This now includes Drupal updates.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $80,000. Last year’s was $72,000.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual maintenance for $80,000.
24. Trace3(Barracuda CloudGen Firewall)
Business case:
Trace3 is responsible to maintain the software & licensing for the Barracuda Email Security Gateway is
an email security gateway that manages and filters all inbound and outbound email traffic to protect
organizations from email-borne threats and data leaks.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $5,743.68, cost last year was $5,521.44.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual maintenance for $5,743.68.
25. Trace3 (Horizon)
Business case:
Trace3 is responsible to maintain the software & licensing for the Horizon servers. This is the software
used for our virtual desktop environment and allowing employees to access certain applications
remotely that do not perform well over a traditional VPN.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $47,335.25, the cost last year $45,386.01.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual maintenance for $47,335.25.
26. Trace3(Imperva)
Business case:

Trace3 is responsible to maintain the software & licensing for Imperva. This is the software used for the
web app firewall maintenance & support utilized by all County Departments.
Pricing:
Cost this year is $16,369.14 the cost last year $16,277.85.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the annual maintenance for $16,369.14.
27. Trace3 – Cohesity M365 Cloud Backups
Business case:
Cohesity is used to backup our Microsoft 365 cloud applications like Outlook, Word, Excel, etc. This tool
is needed because our storage is in the cloud, so the backup needs to be done from the cloud.
Pricing:
The initial purchase was made in 2025 and this is the first year’s maintenance for $69,498.00 The
maintenance runs from 12/1/25-11/30/26.
BOC request:
This request is to approve the purchase of the maintenance & support for $69,498.00.

3. For Software Licenses, Accela may terminate this Order Form in the event the Software is phased out across

5. All Software Licenses, Maintenance, and Subscription purchases are non-cancelable and non-refundable.
6. Pricing is based upon payment by ACH and check. Payment by credit card (including Purchase Cards) for product
and services in this Order Form will be subject to a service charge of 3%. There is no service charge for ACH or
check payment.
7. Customer may purchase additional licenses at the same price and for the same term as the licenses in this Order
Form. Additional licenses purchased in this way will have the same annual price applicable for the purchase period
and will have the same uplift and term dates as Customer’s existing licenses.

SERVICE QUOTE
Macomb County, MI DATE ISSUED: 10/09/2025
120 N. Main St., 2nd Floor EXPIRATION DATE: 2/1/2026
Mt. Clemens, MI 48043
This document defines the services to be provided to Macomb County, MI. This document may be refined, modified,
cancelled, and/or terminated in whole or in part if mutually agreed upon by both parties.
SERVICE DESCRIPTION
ETech Consulting will provide annual professional services, guidance, and support for the Accela Civic Platform product(s).
Specific tasks may include but are not limited to configuration, scripting, customization, report development, interface
development, training, change/release management, and technical support of the Accela Civic Platform.
ESTIMATED PROJECT TERM
January 1, 2026 – December 31, 2026
ASSIGNED CONSULTANTS
• Georgiy Sichinava • Ryan Littlefield • Nan Manning
ASSUMPTIONS
• The agency will provide Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) to assist in gathering and refining requirements
• The agency staff will perform User Acceptance Testing and approval prior to configuration release to Production
• The agency staff will provide technical support while migrating configurations to the agency’s production
environment.
• The scope of work is limited to maintenance and continuous modifications to existing configuration and does NOT
include implementation of new modules/components
• The proposed professional services package includes up to 20 hours of professional services per month
• Up to 20 hours can be rolled over to the following month, with no month exceeding a total of 80 hours.
• Statements specifying hours utilized as well as balance can be sent out monthly (or at customer’s request)
• Additional work beyond hours available in each month will be billed at an hourly rate of $175/hour
• Hours used for project management, program management (i.e. attending meetings, review/discussions sessions
etc.) would count towards the monthly allotted hours.
• ETech Consulting, LLC will assist with documentation and communication of Accela Support related issues.
• ETech Consulting, LLC is not responsible for delays caused by the Accela environment or Accela support.

PAYMENT TERMS AND CONDITIONS
Compensation will be based on a fixed fee of $38,400.00 for the 2026 fiscal year. Agency will issue payment within
payment terms, within net-thirty (30) days of receiving invoice. If the thirty (30) day period falls on a weekend or holiday,
payment should be issued the following business day. Payment to ETech Consulting, LLC should be mailed or made via
ACH.
Agency can roll over up to 20 hours per month. Any work beyond the original 20 hours per month, and qualifying roll over
hours, will be billed based on time and materials. Any hours that exceed 20 hours (or the agreed upon subscription total)
will be charged at ETech’s standard rate of $175/hr.
SERVICE ESTIMATE (Fixed Fee)
ETech Consulting will provide up to 20 hours per month of professional services related to but not limited to developing,
implementing, configuring department reports using SSRS, creating, modifying scripting customization, expression and ASI
configuration, API troubleshooting interfacing with the Accela Civic Platform.
SERVICE QUANT. AMOUNT
ETech Consulting - Accela Professional Services 1 $38,400.00
- Up to 20 hours a month
TOTAL $38,400.00
Thank you for your business!

SEVENTH AMENDMENT
TO
STATEMENT OF WORK
This Seventh Amendment to Statement of Work executed on July 10, 2023 (this
“Amendment”) is entered into as of January 01, 2026 (the “Amendment Effective Date”),
by and between Guidehouse Inc., a Delaware corporation (“Guidehouse”), and Macomb
County (the “Client”).
BACKGROUND
WHEREAS, the Client and Guidehouse executed that certain Statement of Work
dated as of July 10, 2023, as amended by Amendments to the Statement of Work (together,
the “SOW”), for certain services to be provided by Guidehouse in accordance therewith;
and
WHEREAS, Client has requested certain changes under the SOW as described
herein.
NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual agreements and covenants
contained herein and therein and for other good and valuable consideration, the receipt
and sufficiency of which are hereby acknowledged, it is mutually agreed and covenanted
by and between the parties to this Amendment as follows:
The Scope of Work is hereby modified to add the following:
Workday Scope
Guidehouse will provide resources to perform the following activities in support of
Workday:
 Workday Production Support
o Guidehouse will serve as an escalation point for any production incidents that
may arise. Client resources are the first line of support to handle all requests and
tasks, while Guidehouse consultants will dedicate time to help troubleshoot, offer
processing advice, and resolve issues if the Client resources require assistance.
o Guidehouse will assist the Client in the prioritization and escalation (when
necessary) of incidents.
o Guidehouse will provide knowledge transfer associated with the troubleshooting
and resolution of production incidents to the appropriate Client support team
member(s) as needed.
 Workday Sustainability & Optimization
o Configuration & Solutions
o Guidehouse understands that the Client may be experiencing some
challenges with existing Workday processes and configurations. Guidehouse
will provide subject matter expertise on Workday functional areas and best
Page 1 of 3

practices to optimize existing configurations to meet the Client’s needs in the
following areas:
 Business Processes & Configurations
 Security
 Integrations
 Reporting
o Guidehouse will advise, recommend and if requested build solutions once
business requirements are fully understood.
o Recommendations and solutions will be reviewed with and approved by the
Client.
o Solutions will be tested and moved to production by the client, with assistance
from Guidehouse, while adhering to change control procedures.
o Guidehouse will work with the Client to manage requests, deliverables and
their status.
o Guidehouse will provide knowledge transfer associated with each solution
provided.
o Workday Governance & Support Model
o Guidehouse will assist the Client in establishing an overall Workday
Governance & Support Team Model inclusive of operational, tactical and
strategic levels of governance designed to manage the Client’s Workday
program
o Operational
o Change control procedures designed to manage the intake,
prioritization, decision making, requirements gathering,
impact analysis, building, testing and deployment of new
initiatives, solutions and feature functionality provided as
part of the Workday Bi-Annual release support the Client’s
strategic objectives. This can include assistance in
preparing and deploying Workday homepage
announcements for all Workday platforms.
o Well defined support team roles & responsibilities and
recommended training
 Tactical
o Development and maintenance of a rolling adoption roadmap with oversight
by a Change Control Committee responsible for resource planning, provides
direction to the operations team, escalate issues when necessary, stakeholder
engagement and user adoption and ensures timely decision making
 Strategic
o Promotes organizational commitment to the Workday program, aligns program
initiatives with the strategic objectives of the organization, removes obstacles,
measures performance and program value, and provides the resources
necessary to sustain the Workday Program
Page 2 of 3

Client’s Responsibilities
The below outlines responsibilities of Client during performance of this work:
 Provide primary point of contact
 Provide solution requirements
 Provide written acceptance of deliverables
 Provide access to Workday implementation tenants
 Provide timely access to project resources
Timing
Amendment Start Date: 01/01/2026
Amendment Completion Date: 12/31/2026
Fees and Payment
The net change to this Amendment is additional funding in the amount of $249,975.00.

FAIR USE POLICY
General
1.It is important to Nearmap that all customers are able to access the Products and Services. Accordingly, we have devised a Fair Use Policy that applies to the data
usage of the Products and Services.
2.In this Fair Use Policy:
a.Excessive Use has the meaning given to that term in section 7 of this Fair Use Policy;
b.Fair Use Policy means this policy;
c.Nearmap, we, us or our means Nearmap US, Inc.;
d.Products has the meaning given to that term in Your Nearmap Agreement;
e.Services has the meaning given to that term in Your Nearmap Agreement;
f.You or Your means any customer of Nearmap;
g.Your Nearmap Agreement means the agreement pursuant to which Nearmap provides You with various products and services; and
h.Unreasonable Use has the meaning given to that term in section 5 of this Fair Use Policy.
3.We reserve the right to vary the terms of this Fair Use Policy from time to time.
4.This Fair Use Policy is in addition to Your Nearmap Agreement and in the event of any inconsistency between the terms of this Fair Use Policy and the terms and
conditions of Your Nearmap Agreement, Your Nearmap Agreement prevails.
Unreasonable Use
5.We consider Your use of the Products and Services unreasonable where You use it in a manner which is reasonably considered by Nearmap to be fraudulent use, to
be contrary to Your Nearmap Agreement or to adversely affect other Nearmap customers’ use of or access to the Products and Services.
6.Among other things, “fraudulent use” includes resupply of the Products and Services without Nearmap’s consent so that someone else may access or use the
Products and Services or take advantage of the Products and Services.
Excessive Use
7.Excessive Use is a continuing and unreasonably disproportionate use of the Products and Services when compared to other average individual named users.
Nearmap’s Rights
8.Where Your use of the Products and Services constitutes Unreasonable Use and/or Excessive Use, Nearmap may contact You to discuss changing Your usage
pattern so that it conforms with this Fair Use Policy, or to upgrade to a more suitable Product or Service (if applicable).
9.If, after Nearmap has contacted You, Your Unreasonable Use and/or Excessive Use continues, Nearmap may, without further notice to You:
a.restrict Your access to low resolution imagery for the remainder of the month; and/or
b.restrict Your access to low resolution imagery for the remainder of the month until Your data allowance is reset at the beginning of the next month (if applicable);
and/or
c.restrict Your access for the remainder of the month; and/or
d.restrict Your access to Nearmap until Your data allowance is reset at the beginning of the next month (if applicable); and/or
e.immediately cease Your access to Nearmap; and/or
f.exercise any other right available to Nearmap under the terms of Your Nearmap Agreement.

Macomb County Qualtrics License Renewal & Modernization
February, 2025
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Executive Summary:
Macomb County (and the Qualtrics technical team supporting them) has successfully deployed the platform across
approximately 25 different programs and applications throughout the past 2 years of the existing contract. As we work
through the final year of the current contract, additional programs of high-complexity will be deployed adding to the
more than $1M in current estimated ROI. As we consider the forthcoming license renewal, we want to ensure that the
County is provided the most powerful technology available, with few-to-no prohibitive and corporate-imposed
parameters, at little-to-no additional cost. Moreover, we want to ensure that Macomb County is insulated from any price
increases during this period. Our proposal achieves all of these things.
Key Changes:
● License to be upgraded and expanded to our full Customer Experience Management Suite - This will vastly enhance the
available technological capabilities of the toolset by incorporating purpose built features supporting digital applications,
location based applications, enhanced integration options, and more.
● Digital Experience Analytics included - This tool passively captures important web session data to assess UX on all
Macomb County Domains. Through our digital feedback project on macombgov.org we have captured feedback from
roughly 1,000 residents on the status of the new website, and this feedback has identified numerous opportunities for
improvement. In fact, 69% of respondents were unable to find what they were looking for on the website and 76% were
unable to complete the purpose of their visit. Our DXA tool will rapidly identify broken web experiences without needing
to ask anybody what is not working.
● Unlimited Users - This proposal would remove all user caps on the Macomb County license. Currently, Macomb County is
approaching their total user counts (350 across the two brands) and this would allow them to support as many
in-platform users as they see fit - inclusive of local community partners they support via funding and programming.
● License Consolidation - The two brands will be moved under the same license. We will keep the operations and data
separate between the brands to continue to ensure PHI data is protected and within HIPAA compliance, but as back end
capabilities continue to develop it will become increasingly easier to access data between brands where appropriate, as
determined by the County.
● AI Capabilities included - All of our new AI capabilities for the CX Suite will be available in this new license. Additionally,
any new AI capabilities that are developed for this suite over the period of the license will be automatically included as
well.
● X4 Passes - We will provide Macomb County 10 passes to our annual customer conference every year for the duration of
this contract.
● Price Locked In for 3 Years
Year 1 - 2026
Full CX Suite w/ all of the above listed items and more: $813,798.99
Year 2 - 2027
Full CX Suite w/ all of the above listed items and more: $813,798.99
Year 3 - 2028
Full CX Suite w/ all of the above listed items and more: $813,798.99
* 2025 License Spend is $810,419 - This proposal reflects a .4% increase contractually locked in over 3 years regardless
of inflationary shifts

Period. The Service Period will begin on 01/01/2026 and it will end on

Services

(“Sites”) at:
● macombgov.org
Response Time - Service Level Agreement

respond after receiving a Care request via email.

support@ten7.com during standard Agency business hours, Monday to
Friday, 9am to 5pm Central Standard Time (“Office Hours”).
● Requests received will be acknowledged and triaged with an initial time
to response of two (2) business hours during Office Hours.

Drupal Updates

and the last 4 weekly snapshots.

snapshots in 3 offsite locations.
Support Hours

used for bug fixes, new feature development, minor enhancements, user

may provide. Unused hours expire at the end of the Service Period.

agenda_text:
``
Macomb County Board of Commissioners
Joe Sabatini, Board Chair Harold L. Haugh, Vice Chair Sylvia Grot, Sergeant-At-Arms
District 04 District 10 District 03
District 01 – Ken Goike District 02 – Phil Kraf t District 05 – Don VanSyckel District 06 – Joseph V. Romano District 07 – James M. Perna
District 08 – Antoinette Wallace District 09 – Barbara Zinner District 11 – Lisa Wojno District 12 – Michael J. Howard II District 13 – Sarah Lucido
AGENDA
DATE/TIME: Thursday, November 6, 2025, 3:00 PM
COMMITTEE: Joint Public Services and Records and Public Safety Committees
CHAIR: Public Services Chair James M. Perna; Records and Public Safety Chair Joseph V. Romano
LOCATION: Administration Building, One South Main Street, 9th Floor, Mount Clemens, MI 48043
1. Call to Order
2. Pledge of Allegiance
3. Adoption of Agenda
4. Approval of Minutes
a) dated October 9, 2025
5. Public Participation (three minutes max per speaker, related only to issues on the agenda)
6. Public Services Committee Department Recommendations
a) Contract Modification: Z Contractors, Inc. - 18 Mile over the Plumbrook Drain Project (Total
Modification Cost: $105,309.57; Total County Cost 52,654.79) / Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
b) Contract Amendment: Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) - Garfield Road from 14
Mile Road to 15 Mile Road (No Cost to County)
c) Professional Services Agreement: VUEWorks Enterprise Asset Management Software (EAMS) -
(Total County Cost: $1,183,000)
d) Contract: Superior Contracting Group, LLC. - 2025 Roadside Ditch Program (Total County Cost:
$565,932.25) / Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
e) Cost Share Agreement: Chesterfield Township - Roadside Ditch Program - (Total Cost $27,965; Total
County Cost $13,983) / Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
f) Cost Share Agreement: Washington Township - Roadside Ditch Program (Total Cost $64,118; Total
County Cost $32,059) / Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
g) Cost Share Agreement: Shelby Township - Roadside Ditch Program (Total Cost $246,538; Total
County Cost $123,269) / Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
h) Cost Share Agreement: Clinton Township - Roadside Ditch Program (Total Cost $63,956; Total
County Cost $31,978) / Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
i) Cost Share Agreement: Ray Township - Roadside Ditch Program (Total Cost $19,998; Total County
Cost $9,999) / Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
j) Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) 2025 Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality
Improvement (CMAQ) Traffic Signal Upgrade Project (Total Cost $6,562,200, County Cost $662,200)
/ Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
bocmacomb.org

AGENDA – PAGE 2
k) Contract: Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) - 2025 Traffic Highway Safety
Improvement Program (Total Cost: $2,714,750; County Cost: $1,214,750) / Bryan Santo, Director of
Roads
l) Contract: Dan's Excavating, Inc., - 2025 Traffic Signal Modernization Project (Total County Cost:
$3,684,365.23) / Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
m) Cost Share Agreement: City of Warren - Traffic Control Device #1115 - Mound Road at Eckstein
Street (Annual Maintenance Cost $3,000: Total County Cost $2,010) / Bryan Santo, Director of
Roads
n) Cost Share Agreement: City of Sterling Heights and Utica Community Schools - Traffic Control Device
#1124 - Clinton River Road at Donovan Park (Annual Maintenance $3,000: No Cost to County) /
Bryan Santo, Director of Roads
o) Cost Share Agreement: City of Warren - Traffic Control Device #1125 - Schoehnerr Road between 13
Mile Road and Common Road (Annual Maintenance $3,000: No Cost to County) / Bryan Santo,
Director of Roads
p) Subrecipient Agreement: Harrison Township - Dial-A-Ride Program - St. Christopher Street Sewer
Line - Anchorage Street Sewer Line - Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) ($317,500)
Postponed to the December 4, 2025 Public Services Committee
7. Records and Public Safety Committee
8. Records and Public Safety Committee Department Recommendations
a) Resolution 2025-14288: A Resolution Approving the Macomb County 2025-2030 Hazard Mitigation
Plan / Brandon Lewis, Director of Emergency Management and Communication
9. Records and Public Safety Committee Correspondence
a) 2025 State Survey and Remonumentation Program's 17th Biennial Report
10. Public Participation (three minutes max per speaker)
11. Commissioners' Comments
12. Closed Session
a) Closed Session to Discuss US Supreme Court Case #25-451 / Frank Krycia, Assistant Corporation
Counsel
13. Closed Session Recommendations
a) Waived by Government Oversight Commitee Chair
Request for Outside Counsel: Dykema Gossett, PLLC Court Case #25-451 / Frank Krycia, Assistant
Corporation Counsel
14. Adjournment
2025-11-06 BOC Joint Public Services and Records and Public Safety Committees bocmacomb.org

Macomb County Board of Commissioners

title: Meeting
body: Civil Service Commission
location: 120 N. Main St., Mt. Clemens, MI, 48043
agenda_text:
MACOMB COUNTY
CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION MEETING
Wednesday, November 12, 2025, 9:00 AM
120 N. Main, Mount Clemens, 48043
2nd Floor Conference Room
AMENDED AGENDA
1. Call to Order and Roll Call
2. Adoption of Amended Agenda
a) Review and approve the agenda as amended on November 12, 2025
3. Minutes
a) Review and approve the minutes of October 22, 2025
4. Public Participation
5. Business
6. Personnel
a) Review and approve the Corrections Deputy eligibility list
b) Review and approve the Dispatch eligibility list
c) Review and approve the Deputy eligibility list
d) Receive and file requests for pre-employment physical and psychological evaluations for:
Jesse Skiendzior Deputy Recruit
Shane Stec Deputy Recruit
e) Receive and file memo from Undersheriff Darga and Recommendation to Fill Vacant Position
forms for:
Brenden Pfeiffer Deputy Promoted effective October 20, 2025
Parr King Deputy Recruit Hired effective January 5, 2026
f) Receive and file resignation letters and termination forms for:
Albert Burke IV Corrections Deputy Resigned effective October 28, 2025
Stephanie Jarillo Dispatcher Resigned effective October 21, 2025
Erika Robinson Corrections Deputy Resigned effective October 27, 2025

g) Review and approve pre-employment physical and psychological evaluations and recommend
hiring:
Owen Mandoky Corrections Deputy
Shane Stec Deputy Recruit
7. Old Business
8. New Business
a) Review and approve payments to Ascension for pre-employment physical evaluations for:
Cody Knapchuck Invoice #582219 dated 10/6/2025 for $150.00
Parr King Invoice #582685 dated 10/10/2025 for $150.00
Owen Mandoky Invoice #584005 dated 10/28/2025 for $150.00
Total: $450.00
b) Review and approve payment to Harold J. Love & Associates, invoice #2262 dated 10/27/2025 in
the amount of $750.00 for pre-employment psychological exam for Ashley Reinhout
9. Adjournment
Macomb County Clerk’s Office  120 N. Main, Mount Clemens, MI 48043  (586) 783-8142  Fax: (586) 469-5123
minutes_text:
MACOMB COUNTY
CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION MEETING
Wednesday, November 12, 2025, 9:00 AM
120 N. Main, Mount Clemens, 48043
2nd Floor Conference Room
MINUTES
1. Call to Order and Roll Call
The meeting was called to order by the Chairperson at 09:00 AM 120 N. Main Street, 2nd Floor,
Mount Clemens, Michigan 48043.
Present: Robert Stanley, Thomas Stawski, Patrick Maceroni
Others: Corporation Counsel, John Schapka, HRLR, Mia Mezini, Sheriff's Office Lt. Jason Conklin
2. Adoption of Amended Agenda
a) Review and approve the agenda as amended on November 12, 2025
Motion to adopt the agenda as amended on Wednesday, November 12, 2025. THE MOTION
PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
3. Minutes
a) Review and approve the minutes of October 22, 2025
Motion to amend the October 22, 2025 minutes to add 7. Old Business. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
4. Public Participation
NONE.

5. Business
NONE.
6. Personnel
a) Review and approve the Corrections Deputy eligibility list
Motion to approve the above. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
b) Review and approve the Dispatch eligibility list
Motion to approve the above. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
c) Review and approve the Deputy eligibility list
Motion to approve the above. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
d) Receive and file requests for pre-employment physical and psychological evaluations for:
Jesse Skiendzior Deputy Recruit
Shane Stec Deputy Recruit
Motion to receive and file the above. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski

e) Receive and file memo from Undersheriff Darga and Recommendation to Fill Vacant Position
forms for:
Brenden Pfeiffer Deputy Promoted effective October 20, 2025
Parr King Deputy Recruit Hired effective January 5, 2026
Motion to receive and file the above. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
f) Receive and file resignation letters and termination forms for:
Albert Burke IV Corrections Deputy Resigned effective October 28, 2025
Stephanie Jarillo Dispatcher Resigned effective October 21, 2025
Erika Robinson Corrections Deputy Resigned effective October 27, 2025
Motion to receive and file the above. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
g) Review and approve pre-employment physical and psychological evaluations and recommend
hiring:
Owen Mandoky Corrections Deputy
Shane Stec Deputy Recruit
Motion to approve the above. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
7. Old Business
NONE.

8. New Business
a) Review and approve payments to Ascension for pre-employment physical evaluations for:
Cody Knapchuck Invoice #582219 dated 10/6/2025 for $150.00
Parr King Invoice #582685 dated 10/10/2025 for $150.00
Owen Mandoky Invoice #584005 dated 10/28/2025 for $150.00
Total: $450.00
Motion to approve the above payments. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski
b) Review and approve payment to Harold J. Love & Associates, invoice #2262 dated 10/27/2025 in
the amount of $750.00 for pre-employment psychological exam for Ashley Reinhout
Motion to approve the above payment. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski

Motion to adjourn the November 12, 2025 meeting at 09:16 AM. THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Patrick Maceroni
Seconded by: Thomas Stawski
Vote Summary: (3 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Robert Stanley, Patrick Maceroni, Thomas Stawski

title: Meeting
body: Community Mental Health Board - Program and Budget Committee
location: 1 S. Main Street, Mt. Clemens, MI, 48043

published_files.name: 2025-11-12  CMH Board Program and Budget Committee Meeting Agenda
2025-11-12 CMH Board Program and Budget Meeting Packet

agenda_text:
Our Mission: Macomb County Community Mental Health,
guided by the values, strengths, and informed choices of the PEOPLE WE SERVE,
provides quality services which promote
recovery, community participation, self-sufficiency, and independence.
Community Mental Health Board
Phil Kraft Antoinette Wallace Lori Phillips
Chair Vice Chair Secretary/Treasurer
Megan Burke Nick Ciaramitaro Sherita Harvey
Donna Cangemi Wayne Conner Julia Mendyka
Jackie Catinella Dana Freers Selena M. Schmidt
Phil Kraft Antoinette Wallace Lori Phillips
Chair Vice Chair Secretary/Treasurer
DATE/TIME: Wednesday, November 12, 2025, 6:00 PM
COMMITTEE: Program and Budget
COMMITTEE CHAIR/VICE CHAIR: Chair Freers
COMMITTEE MEMBERS: Committee of the Whole
LOCATION: 1 S. Main St., Mt. Clemens - 9th Floor of the Macomb County Building
AGENDA
1. Call to Order
a) Pledge of Allegiance
2. Reading of the Mission Statement
3. Adoption of Agenda
4. Hearing of the Public
5. Request to Approve
a) Request to approve a Special Assessment for the Community Mental Health Association (CMHA) of
Michigan in the amount of $31,022. (Approved by legal)
b) Request to approve a $5,000 voluntary Special Assessment to support the Community Mental
Health Association (CMHA) of Michigan's technical assistance for Certified Community
Behavioral Health Clinics (CCBHC).
c) Request to approve the state amendment to add Infant and Early Childhood Mental Health
Consultation (IECMHC) subgrant agreement to the master agreement for Comprehensive
Behavioral Health (CBH) 2026 between MDHHS and MCCMH. (Approved by legal.)
d) Request to approve the use of the MDHHS approved grant funds for technology-based recovery
supports for materials, programs and software to enhance data collection, care coordination and
engagement with services and supports provided in the MCCMH network.
e) Request to approve the use of the MDHHS approved grant funds for integrated healthcare supplies,
events, promotional materials and evidence-based practice training for the MCCMH network.
f) Request to approve an agreement with Train for Change to provide ASAM 4th Training to
MCCMH contracted SUD providers.
g) Request to approve purchasing Naloxone Bags as a part of the SOR 4 grant not to exceed $15,358.
h) Request to approve the contract with Traci Smith as MCCMH's CEO beginning 1/1/2026.
(Approved by OCE & legal)
6. Receive and File
a) Airfoil - MCCMH Communications Q4 Report
b) Request board approval on receiving an update from the CY 2025 Quality Assessment Performance
Improvement Program (QAPIP) Workplan.

7. Resolutions
8. Other Possible Agenda Items
a) CEO Update
b) REMINDER: CMH Full Board Meeting - TUESDAY, November 25, 2025 @6pm
c) REMINDER: CMH Board Program and Budget Meeting - NO MEETING SCHEDULED
d) REMINDER: CMH Full Board Meeting - Wednesday, December 17, 2025 @6pm
e) REMINDER: CMH Recipient Rights Advisory Committee Meeting - Thursday, December 18, 2025
@8am
9. Provider Comments
10. Hearing of the Public
11. Adjournment

8. Ordinances
a) Ordinance 2025-XX: FY 2026 Comprehensive General Appropriations Ordinance
Amendment to Section 9
Motion to amend Section 9 of the Ordinance as follows:
Section 9. Fund Transfers. The County Executive, Countywide Elected Officials, Departments and
Agencies shall have authority to transfer funds as follows (i) from or to any line item within each
of the budgetary centers in an amount up to $35,000 $25,000 or 5.0% of the budget in that
budgetary center known as a department number, whichever is less, and (ii) to or from any line
item for internal service costs between the budgetary centers known as a department number.
Multiple related expenditures shall be aggregated and subject to the limitation of
$35,000 $25,000 or 5.0%, whichever is less for the budget year.
THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Harold L. Haugh
2025-11-13 BOC Finance/Audit/Budget Committee bocmacomb.org

MINUTES - PAGE 7
Seconded by: Don VanSyckel
Vote Summary: (13 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Ken Goike, Sylvia Grot, Harold L. Haugh, Michael J. Howard II, Phil Kraft, Sarah Lucido, James
M. Perna, Joseph V. Romano, Joe Sabatini, Don VanSyckel, Antoinette Wallace, Lisa Wojno, Barbara
Zinner
Nay - None
Abstain - None
Amendment to Section 10(A)
Motion to amend Section 10(A) of the Ordinance as follows:
Funding for Capital Improvements has been budgeted under the Capital Outlay line item in the
“Non-Departmental” fund 932. Any transfer from that Capital Outlay line item in Department 932
into the Capital Improvement Plan fund requires prior Board approval, which must be in full
compliance with Board’s Capital Improvement Plan Funding Policy, except that any transfer under
$35,000 $50,000 from the Capital Outlay line item in Department 932 for a specific project which
total project cost is under $35,000 $50,000 may be allowed without prior Board approval;
transfers under $35,000 $50,000 made under this exception shall not be divided, separated,
sequenced, phased, or otherwise broken-up in a manner to avoid the requirement of prior Board
approval.
THE MOTION PASSED.
Motioned by: Don VanSyckel
Seconded by: Michael J. Howard II
Vote Summary: (13 - 0 - 0)
Aye - Ken Goike, Sylvia Grot, Harold L. Haugh, Michael J. Howard II, Phil Kraft, Sarah Lucido, James
M. Perna, Joseph V. Romano, Joe Sabatini, Don VanSyckel, Antoinette Wallace, Lisa Wojno, Barbara
Zinner
Nay - None
Abstain - None
Amendment to Section 10(B)
Motion to amend Section 10(B) as follows:
Budget amendments shall be required when the award amount of any federal, state or private
grant fund increases or decreases by $35,000 $25,000 or more. Such budget amendments shall
include details about the amount of the grant, the amounts and sources of any required local
matching funds and a brief synopsis of any restrictions on or requirements for their use. Budget
amendments shall not be required when the award amount of any federal, state or private grant
increases or decreases by less than $35,000 $25,000. However, any such decreases that result in
service delays, disruptions or other negative impact shall be reported to the Commission within
the Quarterly Report or any report of the County financial condition made pursuant to Charter,
Section 3.7.
THE MOTION PASSED.
2025-11-13 BOC Finance/Audit/Budget Committee bocmacomb.org

Nay - None
Abstain - None

and women that serve our great Nation so we can meet here today.
3. Adoption of the Agenda. Motioned by Gonzales, 2nd by Rutherford. Motion carried.
4. Approval of the Minutes of November 4, 2025. Motioned by Slavko, 2nd by Gonzales.

a. Holiday party updates.

body: Board of Commissioners - Full Board
agenda_text:
``
Macomb County Board of Commissioners
Joe Sabatini, Board Chair Harold L. Haugh, Vice Chair Sylvia Grot, Sergeant-At-Arms
District 04 District 10 District 03
District 01 – Ken Goike District 02 – Phil Kraf t District 05 – Don VanSyckel District 06 – Joseph V. Romano District 07 – James M. Perna
District 08 – Antoinette Wallace District 09 – Barbara Zinner District 11 – Lisa Wojno District 12 – Michael J. Howard II District 13 – Sarah Lucido
AGENDA
DATE/TIME: Thursday, November 20, 2025, 3:00 PM
COMMITTEE: Full Board of Commissioners
CHAIR: Chair Joe Sabatini, Vice Chair Harold L. Haugh
LOCATION: Administration Building, One South Main Street, 9th Floor, Mount Clemens, MI 48043
1. Call to Order
2. Pledge of Allegiance
3. Invocation
4. Adoption of Agenda
5. Approval of Minutes
a) Full Board Minutes dated October 23, 2025
b) Closed Session Minutes dated November 4, 2025 and November 6, 2025
6. Public Participation (three minutes max per speaker, related only to issues on the agenda)
7. Appointments
a) Board of Commissioners Independent Counsel
Board Appointment
Effective: December 1, 2025
Dickinson Wright PLLC
8. Proclamations
a) A Proclamation Congratulating E.A. Graphics for Being Named 2025 Sterling Edge Business of the
Year / Joe Sabatini, Board Chair, Joseph V. Romano, District 6, Don VanSyckel, District 5
b) A Proclamation Congratulating Members of Butoku Karate Dojo on Earning Medals at the National
and World Championships / Joe Sabatini, Board Chair, Sylvia Grot, Commissioner, District 3
c) A Proclamation Congratulating Julie Bovenschen for Being Named Court Administrator of the Year /
Joe Sabatini, Board Chair
d) Receive and File - Full Board Approval at November 5, 2025 Internal Services Committee
A Proclamation Awarding the 2025 Macomb County Pat Daniels Veteran of the Year Award / Harold
L. Haugh, District 10 Commissioner and Joseph V. Romano, District 6 Commissioner
9. Presentations
a) BOC Casual Day Recipient Recognition - Macomb Food Program (October 2025) / Macomb Food
Program Board Members Charlotte Carr-McIntyre, Bob Combs and Mike Fontana
10. Finance/Audit/Budget Committee Recommendations
a) Budget Amendment: Central Intake and Assessment Center General Fund Fund Balance ($1,008,971)
bocmacomb.org

AGENDA – PAGE 2
b) Contract: ABF Environmental - Amendment #2 CIAC/CIP Environmental Consulting Services
($188,565)
c) Purchase: LaFontaine Automotive Group - One (1) 2026 Chevrolet Equinox LT AWD ($31,310)
d) Purchase: LaFontaine Automotive Group - (1) 2026 Chevrolet Colorado and (1) GMC Terrain for
Sheriff's Enforcement Team (SET) ($73,200)
e) Macomb County Investment Policy
11. Government Oversight Committee Recommendations
a) Settlement Agreement: USDC Court Case No. 21-cv-10750
b) Request for Outside Counsel: Dykema Gossett, PLLC Court Case #25-451
12. Internal Services Committee Recommendations
a) Agreements: Information Technology - Maintenance Agreements for 1st Quarter 2026
($2,920,008.80)
13. Health and Human Services Committee Recommendations
a) Contract: Paradigm Removal Service - Remains Removal and Transport Services ($75,000)
b) Contract: Heritage Services LLC - Remains Removal and Transport Services ($75,000)
c) Purchase: National Medical Service (NMS) - Forensic Laboratory Services ($150,000)
d) Budget Amendment: Macomb Community Action - CS25-2025-50017 Grant Award
e) Contract: AgeWays - No Wrong Door Program ($125,970)
14. Public Services Committee Recommendations
a) Contract Modification: Z Contractors, Inc. - 18 Mile over the Plumbrook Drain Project (Total
Modification Cost: $105,309.57; Total County Cost 52,654.79)
b) Contract Amendment: Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) - Garfield Road from 14 Mile
Road to 15 Mile Road (No Cost to County)
c) Professional Services Agreement: VUEWorks Enterprise Asset Management Software (EAMS) - (Total
County Cost: $1,183,000)
d) Contract: Superior Contracting Group, LLC. - 2025 Roadside Ditch Program (Total County Cost:
$565,932.25)
e) Cost Share Agreement: Chesterfield Township - Roadside Ditch Program - (Total Cost $27,965; Total
County Cost $13,983)
f) Cost Share Agreement: Washington Township - Roadside Ditch Program (Total Cost $64,118; Total
County Cost $32,059)
g) Cost Share Agreement: Shelby Township - Roadside Ditch Program (Total Cost $246,538; Total
County Cost $123,269)
h) Cost Share Agreement: Clinton Township - Roadside Ditch Program (Total Cost $63,956; Total
County Cost $31,978)
i) Cost Share Agreement: Ray Township - Roadside Ditch Program (Total Cost $19,998; Total County
Cost $9,999)
j) Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) 2025 Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality
Improvement (CMAQ) Traffic Signal Upgrade Project (Total Cost $6,562,200, County Cost $662,200)
2025-11-20 BOC Full Board bocmacomb.org

AGENDA – PAGE 3
k) Contract: Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) - 2025 Traffic Highway Safety
Improvement Program (Total Cost: $2,714,750; County Cost: $1,214,750)
l) Contract: Dan's Excavating, Inc., - 2025 Traffic Signal Modernization Project (Total County Cost:
$3,684,365.23)
m) Cost Share Agreement: City of Warren - Traffic Control Device #1115 - Mound Road at Eckstein
Street (Annual Maintenance Cost $3,000: Total County Cost $2,010)
n) Cost Share Agreement: City of Sterling Heights and Utica Community Schools - Traffic Control Device
#1124 - Clinton River Road at Donovan Park (Annual Maintenance $3,000: No Cost to County)
o) Cost Share Agreement: City of Warren - Traffic Control Device #1125 - Schoehnerr Road between 13
Mile Road and Common Road (Annual Maintenance $3,000: No Cost to County)
15. Resolutions
a) Postponed from the October 23, 2025 Full Board Meeting
Resolution 2025-14186: A Resolution to Levy a Macomb County Millage to Support Capital
Improvements at Martha T. Berry Medical Care Facility
b) Resolution 2025-14157: A Resolution Authorizing Transfer of Certain County Real Property to
Macomb Community College
c) Resolution 2025-14288: A Resolution Approving the Macomb County 2025-2030 Hazard Mitigation
Plan
16. Ordinances
a) Ordinance 2025-02: FY 2026 Comprehensive General Appropriations Ordinance /
17. Board Office Update
a) Monthly Update / Crystal Richardson, Director of Board Operations
18. Correspondence
a) Casual Day Recipient Thank You Letter: Community Housing Network
b) Casual Day Recipient Thank You Letter: Clinton River Watershed Council (CRWC)
c) Invoice: Evans Law Group, P.C. ($6,435)
19. Public Participation (three minutes max per speaker)
20. Other Board/Commission Updates
21. Commissioners' Comments
22. Adjournment
2025-11-20 BOC Full Board bocmacomb.org
